Class Queryable

Provides a set of static (Shared in Visual Basic) methods for querying data structures that implement IQueryable.

Aggregate<TSource>(IQueryable<TSource>, Expressions.Expression<Func<TSource, TSource, TSource>>)

Applies an accumulator function over a sequence.

Remarks

This method has at least one parameter of type Expression whose type argument is one of the Func types. For these parameters, you can pass in a lambda expression and it will be compiled to an Expression.

The Aggregate(IQueryable, Expressions.Expression<>>) method generates a MethodCallExpression that represents calling Aggregate(IQueryable, Expressions.Expression<>>) itself as a constructed generic method. It then passes the MethodCallExpression to the Execute(Expression) method of the IQueryProvider represented by the Provider property of the source parameter.

The query behavior that occurs as a result of executing an expression tree that represents calling Aggregate(IQueryable, Expressions.Expression<>>) depends on the implementation of the type of the source parameter. The expected behavior is that the specified function, func, is applied to each value in the source sequence and the accumulated value is returned. The first value in source is used as the seed value for the accumulated value, which corresponds to the first parameter in func.

To simplify common aggregation operations, the set of standard query operators also includes two counting methods, Count(IQueryable) and LongCount(IQueryable), and four numeric aggregation methods, namely Max(IQueryable), Min(IQueryable), Sum(IQueryable), and Average(IQueryable).

Declaration
public static TSource Aggregate<TSource>(this IQueryable<TSource> source, Expressions.Expression<Func<TSource, TSource, TSource>> func)
Parameters

Expressions.Expression<Func<TSource, TSource, TSource>> func

An accumulator function to apply to each element.
Returns

The final accumulator value.

Applies an accumulator function over a sequence. The specified seed value is used as the initial accumulator value.

Remarks

This method has at least one parameter of type Expression whose type argument is one of the Func types. For these parameters, you can pass in a lambda expression and it will be compiled to an Expression.

It then passes the MethodCallExpression to the Execute(Expression) method of the IQueryProvider represented by the Provider property of the source parameter.

The query behavior that occurs as a result of executing an expression tree that represents calling Aggregate(IQueryable, TAccumulate, Expressions.Expression<>>) depends on the implementation of the type of the source parameter. The expected behavior is that the specified function, func, is applied to each value in the source sequence and the accumulated value is returned. The seed parameter is used as the seed value for the accumulated value, which corresponds to the first parameter in func.

To simplify common aggregation operations, the set of standard query operators also includes two counting methods, Count(IQueryable) and LongCount(IQueryable), and four numeric aggregation methods, namely Max(IQueryable), Min(IQueryable), Sum(IQueryable), and Average(IQueryable).

Aggregate<TSource, TAccumulate, TResult>(IQueryable<TSource>, TAccumulate, Expressions.Expression<Func<TAccumulate, TSource, TAccumulate>>, Expressions.Expression<Func<TAccumulate, TResult>>)

Applies an accumulator function over a sequence. The specified seed value is used as the initial accumulator value, and the specified function is used to select the result value.

Remarks

This method has at least one parameter of type Expression whose type argument is one of the Func types. For these parameters, you can pass in a lambda expression and it will be compiled to an Expression.

The Aggregate(IQueryable, TAccumulate, Expressions.Expression<>>, Expressions.Expression<>>) method generates a MethodCallExpression that represents calling Aggregate(IQueryable, TAccumulate, Expressions.Expression<>>, Expressions.Expression<>>) itself as a constructed generic method. It then passes the MethodCallExpression to the Execute(Expression) method of the IQueryProvider represented by the Provider property of the source parameter.

The query behavior that occurs as a result of executing an expression tree that represents calling Aggregate(IQueryable, TAccumulate, Expressions.Expression<>>, Expressions.Expression<>>) depends on the implementation of the type of the source parameter. The expected behavior is that the specified function, func, is applied to each value in the source sequence and the accumulated value is returned. The seed parameter is used as the seed value for the accumulated value, which corresponds to the first parameter in func. The final accumulated value is passed to selector to obtain the result value.

To simplify common aggregation operations, the set of standard query operators also includes two counting methods, Count(IQueryable) and LongCount(IQueryable), and four numeric aggregation methods, namely Max(IQueryable), Min(IQueryable), Sum(IQueryable), and Average(IQueryable).

All<TSource>(IQueryable<TSource>, Expressions.Expression<Func<TSource, Boolean>>)

Determines whether all the elements of a sequence satisfy a condition.

Remarks

This method has at least one parameter of type Expression whose type argument is one of the Func types. For these parameters, you can pass in a lambda expression and it will be compiled to an Expression.

The All(IQueryable, Expressions.Expression<>>) method generates a MethodCallExpression that represents calling All(IQueryable, Expressions.Expression<>>) itself as a constructed generic method. It then passes the MethodCallExpression to the Execute(Expression) method of the IQueryProvider represented by the Provider property of the source parameter.

The query behavior that occurs as a result of executing an expression tree that represents calling All(IQueryable, Expressions.Expression<>>) depends on the implementation of the source parameter's type. The expected behavior is that it determines if all the elements in source satisfy the condition in predicate.

Declaration
public static bool All<TSource>(this IQueryable<TSource> source, Expressions.Expression<Func<TSource, bool>> predicate)
Parameters
Type Name Description

A sequence whose elements to test for a condition.

A function to test each element for a condition.
Returns
Type Description
Boolean

true if every element of the source sequence passes the test in the specified predicate, or if the sequence is empty; otherwise, false.
Remarks

This method has at least one parameter of type Expression whose type argument is one of the Func types. For these parameters, you can pass in a lambda expression and it will be compiled to an Expression.

The All(IQueryable, Expressions.Expression<>>) method generates a MethodCallExpression that represents calling All(IQueryable, Expressions.Expression<>>) itself as a constructed generic method. It then passes the MethodCallExpression to the Execute(Expression) method of the IQueryProvider represented by the Provider property of the source parameter.

The query behavior that occurs as a result of executing an expression tree that represents calling All(IQueryable, Expressions.Expression<>>) depends on the implementation of the source parameter's type. The expected behavior is that it determines if all the elements in source satisfy the condition in predicate.

Remarks

The Any(IQueryable) method generates a MethodCallExpression that represents calling Any(IQueryable) itself as a constructed generic method. It then passes the MethodCallExpression to the Execute(Expression) method of the IQueryProvider represented by the Provider property of the source parameter.

The query behavior that occurs as a result of executing an expression tree that represents calling Any(IQueryable) depends on the implementation of the type of the source parameter. The expected behavior is that it determines if source contains any elements.

AsQueryable(IEnumerable)

Converts an IEnumerable to an IQueryable.

Remarks

If the type of source implements IQueryable, AsQueryable(IEnumerable) returns it directly. Otherwise, it returns an IQueryable that executes queries by calling the equivalent query operator methods in Enumerable instead of those in Queryable.

This method assumes that source implements IEnumerable for some T. At runtime, the result is of type IQueryable for the same T. This method is useful in dynamic scenarios when you do not statically know the type of T.

Declaration
public static IQueryable AsQueryable(this IEnumerable source)
Parameters
Type Name Description
IEnumerable source
Returns
Type Description
Remarks

If the type of source implements IQueryable, AsQueryable(IEnumerable) returns it directly. Otherwise, it returns an IQueryable that executes queries by calling the equivalent query operator methods in Enumerable instead of those in Queryable.

This method assumes that source implements IEnumerable for some T. At runtime, the result is of type IQueryable for the same T. This method is useful in dynamic scenarios when you do not statically know the type of T.

Exceptions
Type Condition

source does not implement IEnumerable for some T.

Average(IQueryable<Decimal>)

Computes the average of a sequence of Decimal values.

Remarks

The Average(IQueryable) method generates a MethodCallExpression that represents calling Average(IQueryable) itself. It then passes the MethodCallExpression to the Execute(Expression) method of the IQueryProvider represented by the Provider property of the source parameter.

The query behavior that occurs as a result of executing an expression tree that represents calling Average(IQueryable) depends on the implementation of the type of the source parameter. The expected behavior is that it calculates the average of the values in source.

Declaration
public static decimal Average(this IQueryable<decimal> source)
Parameters
Type Name Description
IQueryable<Decimal> source

A sequence of Decimal values to calculate the average of.
Returns
Type Description
Decimal

The average of the sequence of values.
Remarks

The Average(IQueryable) method generates a MethodCallExpression that represents calling Average(IQueryable) itself. It then passes the MethodCallExpression to the Execute(Expression) method of the IQueryProvider represented by the Provider property of the source parameter.

The query behavior that occurs as a result of executing an expression tree that represents calling Average(IQueryable) depends on the implementation of the type of the source parameter. The expected behavior is that it calculates the average of the values in source.

Examples

The following code example demonstrates how to use Average(IQueryable) to calculate the average of a sequence of values.

FirstOrDefault<TSource>(IQueryable<TSource>)

Returns the first element of a sequence, or a default value if the sequence contains no elements.

Remarks

The FirstOrDefault(IQueryable) method generates a MethodCallExpression that represents calling FirstOrDefault(IQueryable) itself as a constructed generic method. The query behavior that occurs as a result of executing an expression tree that represents calling FirstOrDefault(IQueryable) depends on the implementation of the type of the source parameter. The expected behavior is that it returns the first element in source, or a default value if source is empty.

The method does not provide a way to specify the default value to return if source is empty. If you want to specify a default value other than default(TSource), use the DefaultIfEmpty(IQueryable, TSource) method as described in the Example section.

Examples

The following code example demonstrates how to use FirstOrDefault(IQueryable) on an empty sequence.

System.Linq.Queryable#37

Sometimes the value of default(TSource) is not the default value that you want to use if the collection contains no elements. Instead of checking the result for the unwanted default value and then changing it if necessary, you can use the DefaultIfEmpty(IQueryable, TSource) method to specify the default value that you want to use if the collection is empty. Then, call First(IQueryable) to obtain the first element. The following code example uses both techniques to obtain a default value of 1 if a collection of numeric months is empty. Because the default value for an integer is 0, which does not correspond to any month, the default value must be specified as 1 instead. The first result variable is checked for the unwanted default value after the query is completed. The second result variable is obtained by calling DefaultIfEmpty(IQueryable, TSource) to specify a default value of 1.

Remarks

The expected behavior is that the outerKeySelector and innerKeySelector functions are used to extract keys from outer and inner, respectively. System.Linq.Queryable#45

Sometimes the value of default(TSource) is not the default value that you want to use if the collection contains no elements. Instead of checking the result for the unwanted default value and then changing it if necessary, you can use the DefaultIfEmpty(IQueryable, TSource) method to specify the default value that you want to use if the collection is empty. Then, call Last(IQueryable) to obtain the last element. The following code example uses both techniques to obtain a default value of 1 if a collection of numeric days of the month is empty. Because the default value for an integer is 0, which does not correspond to any day of the month, the default value must be specified as 1 instead. The first result variable is checked for the unwanted default value after the query is completed. The second result variable is obtained by calling DefaultIfEmpty(IQueryable, TSource) to specify a default value of 1.

The query behavior that occurs as a result of executing an expression tree that represents calling SingleOrDefault(IQueryable) depends on the implementation of the type of the source parameter. The method does not provide a way to specify a default value. If you want to specify a default value other than default(TSource), use the DefaultIfEmpty(IQueryable, TSource) method as described in the Example section.

Examples

The following code example demonstrates how to use SingleOrDefault(IQueryable) to select the only element of an array. The second query demonstrates that SingleOrDefault(IQueryable) returns a default value when the sequence does not contain exactly one element.

System.Linq.Queryable#83

Sometimes the value of default(TSource) is not the default value that you want to use if the collection contains no elements. Instead of checking the result for the unwanted default value and then changing it if necessary, you can use the DefaultIfEmpty(IQueryable, TSource) method to specify the default value that you want to use if the collection is empty. Then, call Single(IQueryable) to obtain the element. The following code example uses both techniques to obtain a default value of 1 if a collection of page numbers is empty. Because the default value for an integer is 0, which is not usually a valid page number, the default value must be specified as 1 instead. The first result variable is checked for the unwanted default value after the query is completed. The second result variable is obtained by calling DefaultIfEmpty(IQueryable, TSource) to specify a default value of 1.

System.Linq.Queryable#133

source has more than one element.

The query behavior that occurs as a result of executing an expression tree that represents calling TakeWhile(IQueryable, Expressions.Expression<>>) depends on the implementation of the type of the source parameter. The expected behavior is that it applies predicate to each element in source until it finds an element for which predicate returns false. It returns all the elements up until that point.

ThenBy<TSource, TKey>(IOrderedQueryable<TSource>, Expressions.Expression<Func<TSource, TKey>>)

Performs a subsequent ordering of the elements in a sequence in ascending order according to a key.

Remarks

This method has at least one parameter of type Expression whose type argument is one of the Func types. For these parameters, you can pass in a lambda expression and it will be compiled to an Expression.

The ThenBy(IOrderedQueryable, Expressions.Expression<>>) method generates a MethodCallExpression that represents calling ThenBy(IOrderedQueryable, Expressions.Expression<>>) itself as a constructed generic method. It then passes the MethodCallExpression to the CreateQuery(Expression) method of the IQueryProvider represented by the Provider property of the source parameter. The result of calling CreateQuery(Expression) is cast to type IOrderedQueryable and returned.

The query behavior that occurs as a result of executing an expression tree that represents calling ThenBy(IOrderedQueryable, Expressions.Expression<>>) depends on the implementation of the type of the source parameter. The expected behavior is that it performs a secondary sort of the elements of source based on the key obtained by invoking keySelector on each element of source. All previously established sort orders are preserved.

Remarks

This method has at least one parameter of type Expression whose type argument is one of the Func types. For these parameters, you can pass in a lambda expression and it will be compiled to an Expression.

The ThenBy(IOrderedQueryable, Expressions.Expression<>>) method generates a MethodCallExpression that represents calling ThenBy(IOrderedQueryable, Expressions.Expression<>>) itself as a constructed generic method. It then passes the MethodCallExpression to the CreateQuery(Expression) method of the IQueryProvider represented by the Provider property of the source parameter. The result of calling CreateQuery(Expression) is cast to type IOrderedQueryable and returned.

The query behavior that occurs as a result of executing an expression tree that represents calling ThenBy(IOrderedQueryable, Expressions.Expression<>>) depends on the implementation of the type of the source parameter. The expected behavior is that it performs a secondary sort of the elements of source based on the key obtained by invoking keySelector on each element of source. All previously established sort orders are preserved.

Zip<TFirst, TSecond, TResult>(IQueryable<TFirst>, IEnumerable<TSecond>, Expressions.Expression<Func<TFirst, TSecond, TResult>>)

Merges two sequences by using the specified predicate function.

Remarks

The Zip(IQueryable, IEnumerable, Expressions.Expression<>>) method generates a MethodCallExpression that represents calling Zip(IQueryable, IEnumerable, Expressions.Expression<>>) itself as a constructed generic method. It then passes the MethodCallExpression to the CreateQuery(Expression) method of the IQueryProvider represented by the Provider property of the source1 parameter.

The method merges each element of the first sequence with an element that has the same index in the second sequence. If the sequences do not have the same number of elements, the method merges sequences until it reaches the end of one of them. For example, if one sequence has three elements and the other one has four, the resulting sequence will have only three elements.

Declaration

The method merges each element of the first sequence with an element that has the same index in the second sequence. If the sequences do not have the same number of elements, the method merges sequences until it reaches the end of one of them. For example, if one sequence has three elements and the other one has four, the resulting sequence will have only three elements.
